title: Rotational kinematics - average angular fan speed

content.question:
Angular Displacement
Elapsed Time

Fan <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>

<math alttext="pi radians" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>π</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>rad</mi></math>
<math alttext="3 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>

Fan <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>

<math alttext="4 pi radians" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mi>π</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>rad</mi></math>
<math alttext="4 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>

Fan <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>

<math alttext="3 pi radians" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mi>π</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>rad</mi></math>
<math alttext="1 second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>

Three fans undergo different angular displacements over different time intervals. The angular displacement and elapsed time for each fan is described in the table. Which of the following correctly compares the average angular speed <math alttext="omega" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ω</mi></math> of the fans?

choices.label: <math alttext="omega sub 2 is greater than omega sub 1, which is greater than omega sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="omega sub 2 is greater than omega sub 3, which is greater than omega sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="omega sub 3 is greater than omega sub 1, which is greater than omega sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="omega sub 3 is greater than omega sub 2, which is greater than omega sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="omega sub 3 is greater than omega sub 2, which is greater than omega sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
